Run as far as you can, as fast as you can, and never click on this video ever again, if you care about your life at all! But if you have, welcome! Here's a refresher. It's a 1 to 1 replica of the real world.

videos.title: I Survived Sensory Deprivation Ryan: Sensory deprivation is straight up scary. What does it even mean to experience nothing? Especially when my screen time is ten hours a day, which led my father to say this. Ryan's dad: I bet you can last a few hours in one of these.
videos.transcript: Time: 00:00 - 00:10 Ryan: Okay. He might be right, but I'm too insecure to accept that, so I bet him that I could. And whoever loses the bet, has to paint themselves green and say in front of all of Time: 00:10 - 00:20 you... Ryan's dad: What are you doing in my swamp? On camera? Ryan: Next thing I know, I'm outside of a building that's probably on the cover of a Goosebumps book. It didn't take long to find the entrance and immediately be terrified by a Time: 00:20 - 00:30 cat waving at me, as well as a plethora of ducks. Why are there so many ducks here? That is a Superduck. I nervously waited for a few minutes when I was greeted by a man named Tom, legally known Time: 00:30 - 00:40 as the Master of Senses. I was then guided to the world's largest sensory deprivation pool. I'm not scared, you're scared. Time: 00:40 - 00:50 I feel like I walked into a nether portal at some point back there. You're telling me this isn't the most ominous door you've ever seen? Bruh! Time: 00:50 - 01:00 I'm gonna be doing the maximum legal time in this thing. 3 hours. One with no gravity, one with no gravity or light, and one with no gravity, Time: 01:00 - 01:10 light or sound. Complete sensory deprivation, which apparently can have some side effects. I'm a little scared of hallucinating, like in a Simpsons episode, they hallucinate, so Time: 01:10 - 01:20 it must be true. But first I checked how deep the water is because I can barely swim, which Tom thought was hilarious. And now I'm ready. Time: 01:20 - 01:30 Yay! Oh, my goodness! Whoa! See ya! Tom: So when you get into a floating pool, generally the progression is as follows. Time: 01:30 - 01:40 You get in, you sit down, you lay back, and as you lay back, you float up to the surface of the water. Ryan: Oh, my gosh! Time: 01:40 - 01:50 I feel like a single-celled organism right now. I've got a timer on my phone that's gonna go off at the three hour mark. This pool is saltier than my ex- girlfriend. Time: 01:50 - 02:00 I don't have an ex-girlfriend. You guys know I can't swim really. Well, I can't float either. I am negative, buoyant somehow. So these pools have tons of salt. Time: 02:00 - 02:10 Like 2,500 lbs of salt. Even in Stranger Things, they show them filling up a pool of salt. And salt makes you float. I worked really hard on this visual. Please affirm me! Ryan: But in conclusion... Tom: I's like Time: 02:10 - 02:20 dropping an ice cube into a glass. If it's a person's first time, it's going to take maybe 5 to 10 minutes for them to start Time: 02:20 - 02:30 to release their body in a way that trusts the water. Ryan: I have never successfully floated before, and this is...well, this is crazy. Time: 02:30 - 02:40 I was only 18 minutes into this challenge when I had the actual scariest experience of my life. What the freak? A duck. Time: 02:40 - 02:50 Of course. Tom: You know, I would say 10 minutes to 20 minutes is, you know, mind dump. Time: 02:50 - 03:00 Ryan: I feel like a butterfly. (Sings:) "It's fun to stay at the Y-M- C-A..." Time: 03:00 - 03:10 Tom: BS. BS. BS. And then maybe around 25 to 30 minutes, the mind just goes, okay. I give up. Ryan: I don't see how Time: 03:10 - 03:20 people fall asleep in here. You know, this is why you don't say stuff like that. I'm completely asleep here, totally vulnerable. But the duck woke me up, and now it's time to turn off the lights. Time: 03:20 - 03:30 No light. Here we go. Turning off the lights added a completely new element to this, that I genuinely didn't Time: 03:30 - 03:40 expect to be that dramatic, but it was. I have lost all concept of time, but I still have my duck with me, so... Time: 03:40 - 03:50 Tom: You know, being glued to a phone or glued to a screen, I think increases, you know, your own personal Time: 03:50 - 04:00 suffering. Time: 01:20 - 01:30 And so...no matter where you are in a reverb room, it doesn't get any louder or any quieter. Time: 01:30 - 01:40 It's a perfectly diffuse room, which means: the sound is the same everywhere. Ryan: For context of loudness: whispering is about 30dB. Thunder: 120dB. Now let's say you go to a rock concert! Time: 01:40 - 01:50 You probably know this by now, but the front row is about 150dB. But in a reverb room, that noise just reflects like, listen to this!
